abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey unsatisfactory
            project outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and modest
            institutional development impacts. Lessons highlight the
            importance of implementing legislative actions prior to loan
            effectiveness, and, the Bank should ensure that sector
            policy, and reform objectives are recorded in a formal
            Letter of Development Policy, regardless whether or not,
            there is an apparent commitment to sector reforms by the
            government. Furthermore, the Bank should not underestimate
            the magnitude of resistance by trade unions and the
            difficulties this brings along to staff, corporate
            management, and the government itself, nor the time required
            to develop sufficient consensus, needed to address
            structural changes in large organizations requiring major
            staff reduction. Similarly, the Bank should not rely on
            studies and expected implementation of their recommendations
            as part of conditionality, an approach by nature too vague,
            difficult to manage, and almost impossible to enforce.
            Additionally, in order to ensure commitment and full
            implementation of technical assistance components, clearly
            defined terms of reference, agreed during appraisal, should
            be ensured by the Bank prior to negotiations. As for the
            lending instrument, investment loans are poorly suited to
            support long-term sectoral reforms; had an adjustable
            program loan been available at project design, effective
            gradual support to sector policy changes would have
            minimized risks and costs, securing incremental
            commercialization, and progressive closure of loss making activities.
